title: ver sacrum
content:
I am trying to find information on a Roman type used by the publisher Philip & Kramer for the Austrian Secessionist magazine “Ver Sacrum.” It may have been produced by Poppelbaum — at least Poppelbaum had a font called “ver sacrum”: it was either the same type or a close copy. Is anyone familiar with it? Does anyone make a digital version?

 [‹ Font ID Help](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643/http:/typophile.com/node/32990 "Go to previous forum topic") [Heavy Italized Font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643/http:/typophile.com/node/32978 "Go to next forum topic")
author: dpl

comments.content: It’s difficult to advise without a sample. But read [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643/http:/www.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/forum/viewthread.php?threadid=53774) for a start. Or aren’t you talking about the masthead? Another good reason for showing the sample.

Here is the Poppelbaum type being used in 1903:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643im_/http:/typophile.com/files/das_andere_6098.jpeg)

Although it obviously isn’t what is being used here, [Parkinson’s Benicia](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/parkinson/benicia/) is similar. The blurb at the MyFonts page just linked includes some research hints. Not sure if they’re of much use. From them, I came across [LTC Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-jenson/). Neither of these match the ’W’ from your scan. (The short tail of the ’Q’ also distinguishes your face from others. Edit: the ’G’ seems even more distinctive.)

Tupper: thanks!

Not an exact match, but LTC Jenson is pretty close — and it, I learn, is based on William Morris’s “Golden Type” of 1890, also a close match. This makes perfect sense, as Austria looked to England for much of its progressive design at the time. The Poppelbaum “ver sacrum” type was certainly just a local variation based on the Kelmscott original. I agree that the “G” is its distinguishing mark; I’m curious where that little spur came from — I can’t recall seeing anything like it.
I’m glad my comments helped. You can find that sort of ’G’ in a Cheltenham.

Here’s a photo of the ’Ver Sacrum’ lettering in Vienna.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211643im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Versac_5835.jpg)
